Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Probe-Based Near Infrared Autofluorescence for Parathyroid Identification

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the probe-based NIRAF group or the control group.

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a single institution, this randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing parathyroidectomy for primary hyperparathyroidism.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the probe-based NIRAF group or the control group.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the efficacy of probe-based near infrared autofluorescence (NIRAF) in enhancing parathyroid identification.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the number of parathyroids identified with high confidence by the surgeon and resident, assessed intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the intervention's nature, blinding was not possible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 160 patients were randomised, with 80 in each group, between [Start Date] and [End Date].

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the probe group, the senior surgeon's identification rate improved significantly from 3.2 to 3.6 parathyroids per patient (p<0.001), while the junior surgeon's rate increased from 2.2 to 2.5 (p=0.001). Residents demonstrated a significant increase from 0.9 to 2.9 parathyroids per patient (p<0.001).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
